elements.name: preamble
elements.html:
Code.org {workshop_course} Professional Learning Program Pre-Survey

Welcome to the program!

Code.org relies on surveys as a crucial tool through which we remain connected to teachers, and to give you the opportunity to provide feedback about our curriculum and your teaching experience, as well as to improve our programs.

Privacy and Confidentiality

  • Your individual responses here are completely confidential.
  • Your identity will never be revealed publicly or used to tie any responses back to you personally.
  • We may share anonymous, aggregate data (representing all responses) publicly.
  • Your anonymized responses will be used by Code.org, our Regional Partners, and our facilitators for program improvement.

This survey should take about 10 minutes to complete. 

Your honesty and candor are appreciated.

elements.name: question1
elements.html:
Teaching Context

First, we have some questions about the context in which you are teaching {workshop_course}. Your responses help us understand issues that may be unique to your local context and allow us to develop programming to provide you with support.

elements.name: required_course_status
elements.title: Is {workshop_course} a required or elective course at your school?

elements.name: course_length_weeks
elements.title: For a typical section of {workshop_course} that you will teach, approximately how many WEEKS will the class run?

elements.name: section_time_minutes
elements.title: At your school, on average, how many MINUTES PER WEEK will a typical section of {workshop_course} meet?

elements.name: teaching_csp_as
elements.title: I plan to teach {workshop_course} as...

elements.name: taught_ap_before
elements.title: Have you taught an AP class before?

elements.name: other_aps_taught
elements.title: What other AP course(s) have you taught?

elements.name: grade_levels_csp
elements.title: I plan to teach CS Principles to students in the following grade levels. (check all that apply)

elements.name: grade_levels_csd
elements.title: I plan to teach CS Discoveries to students in the following grade levels. (check all that apply)

elements.name: years_teaching
elements.title: How many years have you taught at the K-12 level (any subject)?
elements.description: Please enter a whole number. If you are about to start your first year teaching, enter 0.

elements.name: years_teaching_cs
elements.title: How many years have you taught COMPUTER SCIENCE at the K-12 level?
elements.description: Please enter a whole number. Enter 0 if it's your first year teaching computer science.

elements.name: total_pd_time
elements.title: What is the TOTAL amount of time you have spent on professional development related to computer science or computer science teaching in the last 2 years? (reference: a typical weeklong summer workshop is about 35 hours)

elements.name: cs_community
elements.title: How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements about your computer science teaching community?

rows.text: When I need help teaching computer science, I have someone to turn to.
I know computer science teacher-leaders and role models in my community.
I feel like I'm part of a broad computer science education movement.
I see my Regional Partner as a resource and support for computer science education in my community.
I am excited to collaborate with other computer science teachers in my community.

elements.name: true_of_me_now_scale_expl
elements.html:
Self-assessment of Computer Science Teaching Practices

Please use the "true of me now" scale to self-assess your current knowledge and skills teaching computer science. Please think about how true it is that you can do certain things in terms of your own development and preparation for teaching computer science right now.  

 
N/A 1----2 3----4----5 6----7
Irrelevant Not true of me now
 not well prepared, need more development
 Somewhat true of me now
somewhat prepared, in process developing		 Very true of me now
well prepared, current strengths

Below, we ask the degree to which you believe you have concrete teaching strategies. A concrete teaching strategy is a specific teaching technique, method, or named practice that you could describe or demonstrate to another teacher right now, if asked.

elements.name: codedotorg_teaching_strategies_csd
elements.title: Right now, I have concrete teaching strategies to...

rows.text: ensure that students work collaboratively.
ensure that every student has a daily opportunity to share ideas and be heard by classmates through partnered conversations, or small-group or large-group discussions.
create a culture in which problems or failures are normalized and welcomed as a natural part of the problem solving process.
provide frequent opportunities for students to do reflective writing as a way to promote sense-making and self-expression.
create a classroom culture in which students regularly get feedback on their work.
support student understanding and use of CS vocabulary.
differentiate instruction to meet student needs.
create a culture in which students know where to find and how to use resources to support problem solving.

elements.name: true_of_me_now_scale_expl
elements.html:
Self-assessment of Computer Science Teaching Practices

Please use the "true of me now" scale to self-assess your current knowledge and skills teaching computer science. Please think about how true it is that you can do certain things in terms of your own development and preparation for teaching computer science right now.  

 
N/A 1----2 3----4----5 6----7
Irrelevant Not true of me now
 not well prepared, need more development
 Somewhat true of me now
somewhat prepared, in process developing		 Very true of me now
well prepared, current strengths

Below, we ask the degree to which you believe you have concrete teaching strategies. A concrete teaching strategy is a specific teaching technique, method, or named practice that you could describe or demonstrate to another teacher right now, if asked.

elements.name: codedotorg_teaching_strategies_csp
elements.title: Right now, I have concrete teaching strategies to...

rows.text: ensure that students work collaboratively when writing code.
create a classroom culture in which students regularly get feedback on their work from their peers.
ensure that every student has a daily opportunity to share ideas and be heard by classmates through partnered conversations, small-group, or large-group discussions.
create a culture in which problems or failures are normalized and welcomed as a natural part of the problem solving process.
provide frequent opportunities for students to do reflective writing as a way to promote sense-making and self-expression.
support student understanding and use of CS vocabulary.
support students in becoming informed decision makers about the impact of technology.

elements.name: rating_description
elements.html:
Below are pairs of statements from computer science teachers describing various philosophies or approaches to teaching, presented as Statement A and Statement B like so:

Please select the value 1-5 that best shows how closely your own beliefs are to one of the statements in a given pair. Please respond freely based on your personal beliefs and philosophy - there is no right or wrong way to respond.

elements.name: lead_learner_statements
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
"I do not need to have deep expertise in computer science in order to successfully teach it. I have expertise in how to learn, and I can model that for my students as we learn the content together." "As the teacher, I need to have deep content expertise so that I can properly answer students’ questions and guide instruction appropriately."

elements.name: lead_learner
elements.title: Lead Learner. 1. model expertise in how to learn  --- 5. need deep content expertise

elements.name: recruit_responsibility_statements
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
Computer science teachers’ responsibility is to promote their computer science classes broadly, to all students. The diversity of the class will reflect those most interested in taking a computer science class. Computer science teachers have a responsibility to recruit a set of students into their classrooms that are representative of the school’s population in terms of diversity (gender, racial, socio-economic, etc.)

elements.name: recruit_responsibility
elements.title: Recruit Responsibility. 1. recruit students interested in CS  --- 5. recruit representative population

elements.name: prioritize_time_statements
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
It’s important that the teacher prioritize their time and resources for students who have the most need. The teacher should ensure that their time, and students’ access to resources are distributed equally for all.

elements.name: prioritize_time
elements.title: Prioritize Time. 1. prioritize most need --- 5. distribute equally

elements.name: instructional_focus_statements
elements.html:
Statement A Statement B
Instruction and class activities should focus on maintaining high standards and rigor so that students reach the highest level of achievement, even if some students struggle with the material. Instruction and class activities should focus on ensuring that students with the least prior knowledge and preparation are not left behind, even if that means that less material can be covered.

elements.name: instructional_focus
elements.title: Instructional focus. 1. more material,some students struggle --- 5. less material, leave fewer behind

elements.name: question2
elements.html:
Wrap Up and Submit

As a reminder this survey is confidential. We collect this information for program improvement. None of your responses will ever be tied back to you personally.

elements.name: highest_level_cs_education
elements.title: Which most accurately describes the highest level of formal computer science education you have completed?

choices.text: At this time, I have little to no formal education in computer science.
I have taken one or more courses online for credit.
I took one or more courses in college.
I am currently in the process of earning a computer science degree.
I have a Bachelor's degree in computer science.
I have a Master's degree in computer science.
I have a PhD in computer science.

elements.name: assigned_or_chose_to_teach
elements.title: Which of the following most closely applies to you about teaching {workshop_course} next school year:

choices.text: I was assigned to teach the course.
I chose to teach the course.
I am not currently planning to teach the course next year.

elements.name: birth_year
elements.title: What is your year of birth?
elements.description: Please enter a whole number e.g. 1975.

elements.name: gender_identity
elements.title: What is your gender identity?

elements.name: racial_ethnic_identity
elements.title: What is your racial or ethnic identity? [check all that apply]

choices.text: Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander

elements.name: thank_you
elements.html:
Thank you!

Thank you so much for taking the time to complete this survey. Your input and feedback is vital for our programs.
